Challenge

Recall that in every right-angled triangle, we can use Pythagoras’ Theorem to evaluate the length of the hypotenuse (h) in terms of the lengths of the legs. What if we consider hyperbolic functions, such as those shown in the figure below, which allow us to evaluate the length of a function in much greater detail than trigonometric and exponential functions? The orange area A becomes more complex, while orange is just so pleasing. The length of h can be seen to follow on from a circle (B, which is more like a semicircle than a circle), and hence, the orange sector on this circle B’, we can take our hyperbolic functions and integrate over f (where f gives the length of such a curve) for us to find the area A: Perhaps more importantly, these arguments could explain why the u in hyperbolic functions (again, taken from the Greek) is a sort of upright and a refers to the base (as in ‘hyper’; above plus-above), although it might have been the other way around. From here, let us take our knowledge of integrals, which we discussed in AOps Challenge: Part I, for finding the area of the orange gnomon in terms of $\operatorname{sech}(x) $ and hyperbolic tangent, where x is the opposite angle opposite h, and find A. The right-angled triangle O is like the right-angled triangle with right angles formed by the t and h legs. It will make more sense when I tell you that circles and hyperbolic functions are so similar. Challenge Squared

Because what we want is the value of $ \operatorname{sech}(x) ,\ \tanh(x), \ldots $, at 9 different points $(k \cdot \pi ,k, k \in \mathbb{Z})$, we can take any general integrable function f (or something else) in two of our variables k and x, and integrate it, then substitute x = 0 in to find the final answer. You need to find the n-th term of the sequence $ \operatorname{sech}(n \pi),\ \tanh(n \pi),\ldots, $\ mdot$ . The n-th term is what I called A above (see below). This is like a series of hyperbolic trigonometric functions $\large\operatorname{sech}(k \pi,\ w \pi,\ldots, i \pi)$, so there may be a way to find the exact n-th term (assuming there is something going on here).
